article:
'Lugalbanda' is a character found in Sumerian mythology and literature. His name
is composed of two Sumerian words meaning "young king" (lugal: king; banda:
young, junior; small). [http://psd.museum.upenn.edu/epsd/index.html
Pennsylvania Sumerian Dictionary Project] Vanstiphout, H. (2002)
âSanctus Lugalbandaâ in Riches Hidden in Secret Places, T. Abusch (ed.), Winona
Lake: Eisenbrauns, p.260; The name has no such connotations of 'crown
prince'. Lugalbanda is listed in the postdiluvian period of the Sumerian
king list as the second king of Uruk, saying he ruled for 1,200 years, and
providing him with the epithet of the Shepherd. [http://www-
etcsl.orient.ox.ac.uk/section2/tr211.htm English translation of Sumerian King
List in The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature] Whether a king
Lugalbanda ever historically ruled over Uruk, and if so, at what time, is quite
uncertain. Attempts to date him in the ED II period are based on an amalgamation
of data from the epic traditions of the 2nd Millennium with unclear
archaeological observations. Lugalbanda, Reallexikon der Assyriologie 7,
p.117.

Lugalbanda prominently features as the hero of two Sumerian stories dated to
the Ur III period (21st century BCE), called by scholars Lugalbanda I (or
[[Lugalbanda in the Mountain Cave]]) and Lugalbanda II (or [[Lugalbanda and the
Anzu Bird]]). Both are known only in later versions, although there is an Ur
III fragment that is quite different than either 18th century
version Michalowski, P. (2009) âMaybe Epic: The Origins and Reception of
Sumerian Heroic Poetryâ in Epic and History, D. Konstans and K. Raaflaub
(eds.), Oxford: Blackwells. p.13 and n.8; Tablet 6N-T638; as of March 2011
tablet awaits publication. These tales are part of a series of stories
that describe the conflicts between Enmerkar, king of Unug (Uruk), and
Ensuhkeshdanna, lord of Aratta, presumably in the Iranian highlands. In these
two stories, Lugalbanda is a soldier in the army of Enmerkar, whose name also
appears in the Sumerian King List as the first king of Uruk and predecessor of
Lugalbanda. The extant fragments make no reference to Lugalbanda's succession
as king following Enmerkar. For a detailed treatment of Enmerkar and
Lugalbanda stories see: Vanstiphout, H. (2003). Epics of Sumerian Kings,
Atlanta: SBL. ISBN 1-58983-083-0

Lugalbanda appears in Sumerian literary sources as early as the mid-3rd
millennium, as attested by a mythological text from Abu Salabikh that describes
a romantic relationship between Lugalbanda and Ninsun. Jacobsen, Thorkild
(1989) âLugalbanda and Ninsunaâ, Journal of Cuneiform Studies Vol. 41, No. 1,
pp. 69-86

A deified Lugalbanda often appears as the husband of the goddess Ninsun. In the
earliest god-lists from Fara, his name appears separate and in a much lower
ranking than Ninsun, Ninsun ( dLamma-Nin-sÃºn) in Tablet I line 15,
Lugalbanda in Tablet VII line 15. but in later traditions, until the
Seleucid period, his name is often listed in god-lists along with his consort
Ninsun. Exceptions exist. For a full summary of the god-list references
refer to Reallexikon der Assyriologie 7, p.118. Ample evidence for the
worship of Lugalbanda as a deity comes from the Ur III period, as attested in
tablets from Nippur, Ur, Umma and Puzrish-Dagan. Reallexikon der
Assyriologie 7, p.119-20. Nippur tablets indicate that all Ur III kings have
made offerings to the deity Lugalbanda In Old Babylonian period, Sin-
kashid of Uruk is known to have built a temple called Ã-KI.KAL dedicated to
Lugalbanda and Ninsun, and to have assigned his daughter NiÅ¡i-Ä«nÄ«-Å¡u as the eresh-
dingir priestess of Lugalbanda. Reallexikon der Assyriologie 7, p.120

In royal hymns of the Ur III period, Ur-Nammu of Ur and his son Shulgi describe
Lugalbanda and Ninsun as their holy parents, and in the same context call
themselves the brother of Gilgamesh. Reallexikon der Assyriologie 7, p. 131.
See also [http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk/cgi-bin/etcsl.cgi?text=c.2.4.1*# Ur-Namma
hymns] and [http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk/cgi-bin/etcsl.cgi?text=c.2.4.2*# Shulgi
hymns] Sin-Kashid of Uruk also refers to Lugalbanda and Ninsun as his
divine parents, and names Lugalbanda as his god. SjÃ¶berg, Ãke W. (1972) âDie
GÃ¶ttliche Abstammung der sumerisch-babylonischen Herrscher,â Orientalia Suecana
21, p.98

In the Akkadian Epic of Gilgamesh and in earlier Sumerian stories about the
hero, the king of Uruk, Gilgamesh, calls himself the son of Lugalbanda and
Ninsun. In the Gilgamesh and Huwawa tale, the hero consistently uses the
assertive phrase: âBy the life of my own mother Ninsun and of my father, holy
Lugalbanda!â. Ninsumun is another name for Ninsun. Both names Lugalbanda and
Ninsun are written with divine determinatives. For two separate Sumerian
versions of Gilgamesh and Huwawa see [http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk/cgi-
bin/etcsl.cgi?text=c.1.8.1*# ETCSL]. For a discussion of parentage of
Gilgamesh and further references see: George, Andrew (2003), Babylonian
Gilgamesh Epic, Oxford. ISBN 0-19-814922-0, p.107 ff. In Akkadian versions
of the epic, Gilgamesh also refers to Lugalbanda as his personal god, and in one
episode presents the oil filled horns of the defeated Bull of Heaven "for the
anointing of his god Lugalbanda". George, p.629.
